'A website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. It said that when you say, "Hey, I’m here," you are telling everyone, even people you don’t know. This shows that sharing too much online can be bad. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. We share stories and photos, but sometimes we share too much and it can be dangerous. 
A long time ago, some people started sharing their lives online. They were the first bloggers. They lost jobs and friends because of what they shared. One of them was Justin Hall. In 1994, he started sharing his life on the internet. He wrote about everything, even personal things. But one day, he had to stop because it made people not trust him.
Another person, Heather Armstrong, wrote about her job on her blog. Someone at her work saw it and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But later, Heather started writing again about her family and became very popular. She learned to share carefully.
The internet lets us say anything, but we should be careful about what we share.'

'Some scientists talked about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know? This movie mixes documentary and drama. It says there is a lot about our universe we do not understand. Some scientists did not like the movie. They said it was bad and dangerous. In the movie, scientists say the universe is stranger than we think. The movie talks about water changing because of thoughts. It shows pictures of ice crystals looking nice after happy thoughts and bad after sad thoughts. Some people believe this, but many scientists do not. They want more proof. The movie says the universe is very strange. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and a force called 'dark energy'. Other discoveries are also amazing. Scientists found that our brain sees things a little late. They also found where modern humans came from. Some scientists think life on Earth is linked to the universe's design. Science is not finished. We still have a lot to learn. Some scientists are trying to find a Theory of Everything to explain the universe. Many people think the universe is incredible.'

'I like writing short stories more than writing novels. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. I do both, and they help each other. When I finish a novel, I want to write short stories. When I finish short stories, I want to write a novel. I never do both at the same time. I started writing short stories in 1984. It was hard at first, but I enjoyed it. One of my first short stories was ‘Breaking Waves’. It was in my first short-story book, Tales from Abroad. Short stories are quick to write. It takes me about a week to write one. Novels take a year or two. Short stories can come from small ideas, like a word or an image. If a short story is not good, it is okay. Not all stories are great. I learn from my short stories to write better novels. Short stories are like small shadows I leave in the world. They are special to me, and I like to share them with my readers.'

'Science is very important. It helps us in many ways. Science can make us healthy, but it can also be dangerous. Science tries to understand small things like ants and big things like the universe. Science changes a lot. Scientists often find new ideas. Sometimes, these new ideas change what we believe. Long ago, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Now, we know more. Scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein helped us learn new things. Science is not always easy to understand. It is important for everyone to know about science. Science can change our world. It can help us, but we must be careful. Science is part of our future.'

'Around 2015, big book companies saw that ebook sales stopped growing. Some even went down. This made people wonder if ebooks are good for the future. One book company worker said that ebooks made them forget how good paper books are. People still ask if ebooks will replace paper books. This question makes us think a lot. Why do we think ebooks and paper books are fighting? This is not new. When TV came, people thought radio would go away. But radio stayed. People listened in cars and at work. Long ago, people thought audiobooks would replace paper books. Many new things like movies, radio, and phones were said to end paper books. But paper books are still here. We like old things when new things come. When e-readers came, people liked old books more. They liked how they feel and smell. This shows that paper books will not go away soon. We like stories about change. They help us understand new things. We are excited about new things but also scared to lose old things.'

'Every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how famous people from the past 400 years did their best work. I wanted to know how they used their time each day to be creative and productive. I wrote about their daily lives – when they slept, ate, and worked. I wanted to show their habits and routines. 
The book is called Daily Rituals. It is about people's routines. A routine is something you do every day. It can help you use your time well. The psychologist William James said good habits can help us do more interesting things. But he was also a procrastinator and did not always follow a schedule.
I got the idea for this book one Sunday. I was at work, trying to write a story. But I was wasting time, cleaning my desk and making coffee. I am a 'morning person' and work best in the morning. That day, I looked online for other writers' schedules. I found many stories and thought someone should collect them. So, I started a blog called Daily Routines. Now, it is a book.
For the book, I collected many stories about people's routines. I used letters, diaries, and interviews. I also used biographies and articles. I thank all the writers and researchers who helped me. You can find all my sources in the Notes section for more reading.'

'Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father said they could not go on holiday to Spain because it was too expensive. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found a fossil on the beach. He knew he wanted to study fossils. At university, he decided he liked studying very old fossils. He did not want to study dinosaurs. He finished his studies and wanted a job. He applied for a job at Tavistock College in London. On the day of the interview, the professor who liked another candidate had an accident and could not come. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, gave Howard the job. Howard was happy to get the job. He liked his work. One day, someone stole his briefcase with his lecture notes. He was upset but went for coffee. There, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. The visitor told him about new fossils. Howard decided to go to Nairobi to study them. This was a big chance for him.'

Charles Spence likes to eat many different foods. He is a professor at Oxford University in the UK. At home, he has ice cream made from bee larvae. It looks like bugs but tastes a bit like nuts and flowers. Spence studies how our senses work together to change how we taste food. He helps big food companies and famous restaurants with his research. 
Spence wrote a book called "The Perfect Meal" with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman. The book has many interesting facts about eating. For example, the first person to order food in a group usually enjoys their meal the most. Also, people eat more when they are with others.
Spence's lab in Oxford is simple. He uses old equipment to keep costs low. This way, he can work with chefs who cannot pay for research. His work is often paid for by big food companies. These companies want to reduce salt and sugar in their products without customers noticing. 
Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous chef, while working on a project. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea" that uses sound to change how food tastes. Spence found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. 
An airline will soon use music to change how food tastes for passengers. A brand also made an app that plays music while ice cream softens. At home, Spence has fun dinner parties with different sounds and lights to see how they change the taste of food.

'Our brains are very busy. We have a lot of information to look at, like facts and rumours. We have to decide what is important and what is not. We also do many things ourselves now. Before, travel agents helped us with flights, and salespeople helped us in shops. Now, we do these things on our own. We try to do many things at once, like work, family, hobbies, and watching TV. Our smartphones help us do this. But, doing many things at the same time is not good. Earl Miller, a scientist, says our brains are not good at multitasking. We switch from one thing to another very fast, and this is not good for our brains. It makes us less efficient. Multitasking can make us stressed and confused. It can also make us want more new things to look at. Our brains like new things, so it is easy to get distracted. Just having the chance to multitask can make us do worse. Glenn Wilson, a professor, says that trying to focus when you have an unread email can make you less smart. Russ Poldrack, another scientist, found that learning while multitasking puts information in the wrong part of the brain. If students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part of the brain for facts. Multitasking also means making many decisions, which is hard for our brains. Even small decisions can make us tired and lead to bad choices. Many people say email is a problem because there is too much of it. A scientist's son said his dad just answers emails all day, and the dad agreed. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do that and other things too.'

'In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete at night to throw at people during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think about these questions. Animals did things, and science wrote down what they did. People did not think animals had feelings. But now, some scientists are looking at animal feelings. Books like "Wild Justice" and "Do Fish Feel Pain?" talk about this. There is a big question: do animals have feelings like people? In one study, cows opened a gate to get food. The cows that opened the gate by themselves were happier. They jumped and kicked. This makes people think about eating beef. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe says we should stop eating meat. He thinks this is a big change, like when slavery ended. Professor Aubrey Manning says we should think again about how smart animals are. He thinks animals have a simple mind. Professor Euan MacPhail says we should not think animals are like people. The big question is: can we know what it is like to be an animal? Balcombe talks about an experiment with birds called starlings. Some starlings lived in nice cages, others in bad cages. The birds in nice cages ate bad food when they had no choice. The birds in bad cages did not eat. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages were sad. He says one day we will think about animals like we think about racism now. Professor Manning agrees with him. He says people used to think animals were like us, then they changed their minds. Now, people are thinking about it again. It is a hard topic, and people have strong opinions.'

'Thinking is how we understand what we read or hear. Adrian West, a teacher, says that arguing can help find the truth. Technology helps us store and use information, but it can also change how we solve problems. We see a lot of opinions and ideas that can confuse us. More information does not always mean better thinking. Reading books has gone down, and this might hurt our thinking skills. Patricia Greenfield, a teacher, says that watching videos and doing many things at once can make it hard to focus. We do not know exactly how technology affects thinking. Computers and games can be good or bad for thinking. Reading helps us think and imagine, but videos do not. Some videos help us process information quickly, but they do not give time to think deeply. Young people might not use their full abilities because of this. How we see technology affects how we think. Video games can be fun and also help us learn. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach us to make decisions and think in a real-world way. In the digital age, we need to understand how technology changes our thinking.'

Matthew Crawford works as a motorcycle mechanic. Before this, he worked in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about how working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how hard it is to focus today. He noticed this when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford thinks these ads make it hard for us to think. We are always interrupted, so we stop talking to people. We use phones and games a lot, which can take over our lives. Many people feel the same way. For example, some people complain about emails but still check them all the time. Phones on the table can distract us. We have many choices now, and it is hard to control ourselves. We send texts instead of talking to friends. Crawford says this is not good for society. He gives an example of a gym. Before, people shared music, but now everyone listens to their own music. This means people do not connect as much. Crawford has two ideas to help. First, we need less noise and distraction in public. Second, we should do things that need skill, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us focus on real things. They make us use our judgment and connect with others. This way, we can pay better attention to what matters.

"What do you do for work? This is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. I am a philosopher, so it is a bit hard to answer. Saying 'I am a philosopher' can sound strange. People might think philosophers know special things. But this is not true. Philosophers are like everyone else. 
Why do people think philosophers are different? One reason is that philosophers think a lot about life. A long time ago, a Greek philosopher named Aristotle said thinking about life is very good. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said we should think about our lives to make them better. 
Thinking about life does not mean reading many books. It means looking at our daily life and making sure it is good. It is important to share this thinking with others. But today, many philosophers work in universities and talk only to other philosophers. This makes it hard for people to understand them. 
I work in ethics, which is about what is right and wrong. I ask if things people do are good or bad. But philosophy is more than this. It helps us think about our actions and beliefs. By thinking, we can help everyone."

'People who love food think about what and how we eat. In history, people talked about food to explain other ideas. For example, the Greek philosopher Epicurus talked about pleasure and pain. Today, his name is linked to enjoying food and drink. We see his name in restaurants and food shops. Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and we share it with others. We eat with friends and family. Food critics talk and write about food. They are good at describing tastes. Some people say food can be beautiful like art. But food is eaten, so it is different from art. There are questions about what we should eat, like organic or vegetarian food. These choices show our beliefs. Cooking at home is different from cooking in restaurants. At home, we cook for love and friendship. In restaurants, chefs cook for work. Food can help people from different cultures come together. We can learn about others by eating their food. This helps us understand each other better.'

'Rob Daviau is from the US. He makes special board games called ‘legacy’ games. When he was a child, he played many board games. But he thought they were not fun or hard enough. So, he wanted to change them. He asked, "Can board games have a story? Can choices in one game change the next game?" He changed a board game called Risk. He made a new game called Risk Legacy. In this game, choices change the game forever. Players might tear cards or write on the board. Sometimes, they open packets with new rules. The game is played over many sessions. Players remember past games and say, "You did this!" 
Daviau also worked on a legacy version of Pandemic. In this game, players try to stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall. SeaFall is about sailors exploring new lands. Making legacy games is hard. Designers must think about all player choices. They use testers to see how games work. Jaime Barriga tested SeaFall. He said, "It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game is good, then it breaks. Then you must fix it."
Legacy games were not expected to be popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved them. He said, "Legacy games are exciting. You learn new things all the time." Another fan, Ben Hogg, liked the adventure. He said, "At first, I was worried about changing the board. But Pandemic Legacy changed my mind. It’s like watching a new movie."
Legacy games are like TV shows. They have episodes. Daviau wanted to write for TV, but he became a game designer. He likes telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock said making a legacy game is like writing a book. You need to know the start and end. Daviau wants others to try new ideas. But he thinks gamers will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who works on SeaFall, thinks legacy games change how we see board games.'

'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People like stories about animals escaping, like rats and llamas, because they think animals are like us. Octopuses are very smart. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells for protection. Some people think animals are not like humans, but Dr. Frans de Waal says animals are smarter than we think. He studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees. He says animals can think about the past and future, show empathy, and understand others. In the past, people thought animals were smart. Charles Darwin, who studied evolution, said animals and humans are not so different. But in the 20th century, people started to see animals as simple machines. Now, Dr. de Waal believes we are learning more about animal intelligence. He says animals have different skills. For example, squirrels can remember where they hide nuts. Inky’s story might not be true, but it helps people appreciate animal intelligence. Dr. de Waal did an experiment with monkeys. He found that monkeys can feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset. A video of this experiment showed people that animals have feelings too.'

'Robots are machines that can do work. They are becoming more common in many jobs. In the past, robots were mostly in car factories. Now, they are in many places. Some people think robots will do most jobs in the future. But many people also think their own jobs are safe. This is not true. All jobs will change because of robots. For example, a robot in Australia can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than humans. In the USA, a robot helps in supermarkets. It checks if goods are on the shelves. Robots cannot fix themselves yet. This means new jobs for people who can fix and program robots. But some people worry that robots will take away jobs that need people skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang studies robots and jobs. He says robots will work with people soon. Many companies will have a robot manager. There will be more jobs in robots, but not enough skilled workers. People need to learn new skills. Robots will also be in our homes. They will help us in new ways. This is a big chance for companies, but also a challenge. We need new rules to keep us safe. Many jobs might go away, so education is important. We need more people to study science and technology to be ready for the future.'

George Mallory, a famous climber, was asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He said, "Because it's there." People often wonder why anyone would do something so dangerous. Some think climbing is about adventure and fun. A writer named Tejada-Flores wrote about climbing in 1967. He said there are different types of climbing, like climbing small rocks or big mountains. Each type has its own rules. Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. But sometimes, climbing can feel limiting, like when stuck in a tent during a storm. Joe Fitschen, a US climber, thinks climbing is in our nature. He says we like challenges, even if they are risky. Another writer, Brian Treanor, says climbing can teach us good qualities like courage and respect for nature. Some climbers believe that climbing without help or technology is more special. Ebert and Robinson, two expert climbers, think these climbs deserve more recognition. But this idea can be dangerous. Climbing can also be like meditation, helping people find peace. This is similar to Zen philosophy. These are some reasons why people like to climb.

'Alfred Brendel is a famous piano player. He played piano for many years. He is very smart and serious. He played music from Europe. He did not teach many students. But one day, a young boy named Kit Armstrong asked him for lessons. At first, Brendel said no. But then he heard Kit play. Kit played very well. Brendel decided to teach him. Kit is now 19 years old. He likes to learn new things like languages and math. He also writes music. Brendel thinks Kit is very talented. But Brendel does not want people to expect too much from Kit. Brendel is now 80 years old. He does not play piano in public anymore. But he still thinks about music.'

'When I was little, I thought gardens were special places. My grandad's garden was by a river. You could hear the water and birds. I thought all gardens were like this – quiet and peaceful. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old windows. My dad was quiet at home. He liked to say, ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ which means ‘I don’t mind.’ He left school and became a plumber. He didn’t love plumbing. He and Mum once thought about moving to Canada, but they didn’t. Dad was good at fixing things at home. My parents moved house only once. But Mum liked to change furniture. One day, we got a piano. I was scared of it, but I liked the brass candlesticks on it. Mum took them away. My sister got piano lessons, not me. Mum said I wouldn’t have practiced. I liked the river best. I would go there with a fishing net and sandals. I looked for fish to catch and take home. But they didn’t live long, so I put them back in the river. I wanted to leave school early. One day, Dad said there was a job for an apprentice gardener. He thought I might like it. Dad didn’t like gardening, but he saw I did. I think he hoped it would be good for me.'

'Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck in Scotland. The wind is very strong, but Lawrence is happy on his island. He shows me the other islands. He says, ‘That island is Eigg. The one next to it is the Isle of Rum. It rains a lot there.’ I see the rain on the mountains. Lawrence says, ‘I have sheep to move.’ We walk down the hill. He tells me about the island. It is three km long and half as wide. The MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. Lawrence has a sheepdog named Tie. Tie is not doing a good job with the sheep. Lawrence says, ‘Tie, that will never do.’ The Isle of Muck is run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son, Colin, manages the cottages. Their daughter, Mary, and her husband, Toby, run the hotel. Mary and Toby’s children play on the island. They come home when they are hungry. The island has electricity only sometimes. I wait for the lights to turn on. In the morning, Mary makes breakfast with a torch. There is no mobile phone service. Mary says, ‘There is mobile reception on the hill.’ I put my phone away. The boat brings groceries and musicians. They play music in the tearoom. Everyone enjoys it. Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. Her father bought a farm on the Isle of Soay. Jenny went to manage it. She had good typing skills. It rains a lot on the island. I eat fresh fish from the island. Mary cooks it for dinner. The next day, I wait for the ferry. Many ferries were cancelled because of high seas. If my ferry doesn’t come, I will stay on Muck for two more days. I secretly hope to stay.'

'The video game industry is growing. It used to be seen as just a hobby, but now it is serious work. Making video games is hard. It needs many people and a lot of time. Jim Donelly, who works for a games magazine, says it is hard to get a job in big companies. But the industry needs more game designers. Not just the bosses, but also people who make parts of the game. Jim says the best way to get into the industry is to make games. You need to show what you can do. John Field, another expert, says it is not easy. Many people want to work in games, but not everyone has the skills. A good course in games can help. Most game designers start as programmers or artists. They like all kinds of entertainment and art. They are not just fans; they are interested in the future of games. Connections with people in the industry can also help. Games are not just for kids anymore. Families play together, and there are many games on phones and social media. John thinks there are many chances to grow in this industry. Games are fun and can also teach us things.'

'When I was a child, I loved to play football. My dad helped me, but he did not force me. I had a friend whose dad was very strict. My friend stopped playing football because of this. I am happy my dad was not like that. People say my goals are lucky, but I practice a lot. The best players practice for many years. I teach kids to enjoy learning football skills. At school, I played many sports like baseball and basketball. I know education is important, but I only thought about football. I want my son to learn and read. We read him books, but he likes to kick them. When I started playing professional football, the manager helped us young players. He did not make a big deal about it. We knew we had to work hard. We lost the first game, and a TV presenter said we could not win with young players. This made us work harder. I have a lot of money, but it can cause problems. People ask why my mom still works. I help my parents with money, but they like to work. My mom is a hairdresser and loves her job. I like to help my family with my money. After I stop playing football, I want to take a break and do things like skiing. I cannot ski now because if I get hurt, I cannot play football.'

'We lived at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my dad’s agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn’t write in Los Angeles, so Sam found us a cheap place to live. Reef Point was quiet in the summer because of sea fogs. The road was not nice, and most people went to La Carmella instead. Only people with no money or who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, many people came. My dad was busy writing a script and didn’t notice me much. I went to the beach with my dog, Rusty. We didn’t have a dog at first, but Rusty came to us. I gave him water, and he stayed. My dad said, ‘He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and brought me things he found. Sometimes he brought things that weren’t his, like a sneaker or towel, and I had to give them back. Rusty liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. One day, my dad went to Los Angeles, and Rusty and I swam all afternoon. We watched surfers. One surfer was very good. She came over and said, ‘Hi, why didn’t you join us?’ I said, ‘I don’t have a surfboard.’ She asked if I was British and visiting. I said, ‘No, I live here. My dad came to write a film script.’ She asked his name. I said, ‘Rufus Marsh.’ She knew his book, Tall as the Morning, and was interested in me after that.'

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship, Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie said it was better to arrive late, but this was wrong. There was a problem with the computer system, and people were upset. Violet wanted to leave. She looked for her phone in her bag, but it was not there. She needed the phone to call the taxi company. Her son Harry always told her to be careful with her phone. Violet asked a couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message to ask her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was at home. Violet was worried because she needed the phone numbers in New York. Finally, the line moved, and Violet got on the ship. She did not like the ship's foyer. It looked like a hotel that tried too hard. She went to the elevator, which was crowded. At last, she reached her room on the twelfth floor. She was happy because it had a balcony. She paid a lot to make sure she could see the sea.

John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction. He wanted pictures for a book about Portage Park in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 photos by Vivian Maier, a street photographer. Maloof now has many of Maier's things: her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives. He also has many movies and audiotapes. Maloof is excited about his find. He says, "I had no idea what it was when I bought it." Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier's life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and grew up in France. She came back to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and always had a camera. She wore big coats, hats, and strong shoes. Maren Baylaender, who knew Maier, said she was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics. Maier loved theatre and movies. She was not very social but liked to take photos and talk to people. She was serious about her photography. Rydzon said, "She was a true artist and did what she wanted." Maier's photos are about women, children, old people, and the poor. Photography expert Larry Silverman finds her pictures interesting. He wonders if she had her own style or copied others. Maloof is still looking at all the negatives. He was not interested in photography before Maier's work. Her photos inspired him to take his own pictures. Maloof wants people to know Maier's name and work. He says, "We want Vivian Maier in the history books."

'Eleanor Catton wrote a book called The Luminaries. It is a very big book with more than 800 pages. The story happens in New Zealand in the 1860s. There are many crimes, and 12 men try to solve them. The book is a murder mystery. Eleanor Catton wanted to make the book fun and exciting. She did not plan the story before writing. She likes to write herself into difficult situations and then find a way out. Eleanor is from New Zealand, and she loves her country. She feels happy when people in New Zealand are proud of her success. She also likes TV drama series and thinks writing for TV could be fun. Eleanor enjoys talking about her work and New Zealand. She says being in different places changes her imagination. But for now, she will stay in New Zealand to write more books.'

**Text for A1 Level:**
Jonny Kinkead is a man who makes guitars. When he was a boy, he liked to use tools in his dad's garage. He also liked to play the guitar. Now, for 40 years, he makes guitars by hand. Jonny says, "I love the guitar. It is amazing how two pieces of wood can make a beautiful sound."
Jonny learned to play the guitar when he was 11 years old. At 16, he wanted a bass guitar. Some people get a job to buy one, but Jonny made his own. He learned how different wood makes different sounds. Jonny and his brothers also made model boats and planes. Their father taught them how to use tools.
Jonny's bass guitar was good, but he did not think about making guitars for a job. He liked painting and sculpture too. After school, he studied architecture at university. But he left because he wanted to do something else. He thought making guitars is like sculpture because you make something people use.
Jonny started making guitars for a living. At first, he also cleaned windows to make money. He sold his first guitars for the cost of the materials. Now, he is known as a good guitar-maker, but he still makes only ten guitars a year.
In the beginning, Jonny went to music festivals to show his guitars. He learned how to price them. Today, it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK. People now know UK-made guitars are good. Jonny says new guitar-makers should take courses, but also learn by trying different things. He believes learning by doing is important.

English people often talk about the weather. This is a common way to start a conversation. A famous writer, Dr. Johnson, said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting. But this is not true. The weather in England is not very exciting. There are no big storms or tornadoes. 
Some people, like Bill Bryson, say the English weather is boring. Others, like Jeremy Paxman, say it is interesting because it is always changing. But the real reason English people talk about the weather is different. Talking about the weather is a way for English people to start talking to each other. It is like saying "Hello" or "How are you?" 
There are three main times when English people talk about the weather: 
1. As a greeting, like saying "Nice day, isn’t it?"
2. To start a conversation, like saying "Ooh, isn’t it cold?"
3. When there is nothing else to talk about, to fill the silence.
So, English people are not really obsessed with the weather. They use weather talk to be friendly and to start conversations.

Alice Leader was in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was talking to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds. She told them the Romans built the wall 120 km long and 5 meters high 1900 years ago. The students chose this trip instead of going to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built. Alice did not have a good answer. She wanted a book to help explain, but she could not find one. So, she decided to write a book herself. Alice stopped teaching after 31 years and started writing in 2001. She said teaching is like acting and is hard work. Writing is exciting but not as tiring. Alice wants her books to be different from other children's books. She likes to teach English and History together. She loves when children go from bored to interested. Writing is like teaching for her. She started writing because her sons were leaving home, and her head teacher suggested a writing course. She wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and said she should publish it. Alice asked for a year off to write her first book. Her husband, Zachary Leader, helps her edit her books. He changes sentences and suggests new words. Alice likes to add more scenes. They work well together.

'To raise money for charity, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are brothers and champion triathletes, had a special race. The race was in the Yorkshire Dales in northern England. Jonny would drive a car on the road, and Alistair would ride a mountain bike across the country. Jonny said, ‘I’m excited! I can stay warm in the car.’ Alistair wore winter cycling clothes and said, ‘I’ve seen Jonny drive, so I might stop for tea!’ The race started at Semerwater lake and ended at Fleet Moss, a high road. Alistair had to go up a steep hill first. They shook hands and started. Alistair rode his bike up the hill, and Jonny drove the car. Jonny soon had a problem with a big tractor on the road. He said, ‘If Alistair wins, it’s because of this farmer!’ Alistair had to carry his bike up the hill. Sheep watched him. Then he went fast downhill. Jonny had trouble with narrow roads in the village. He drove slowly through a stream. Then he drove fast to the finish line. Alistair was also going fast to the finish. Alistair got there first. He asked, ‘Is Jonny here?’ The crowd said no. Alistair was happy. Jonny arrived later and said, ‘Well done.’ He was sad.'

'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, it is very quiet. You bounce the ball on the grass; you serve; you hit it and hear your own shot. The grass, the history, the stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel like you are in a different world. The quiet helps me play better. I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point is over, there is noise: clapping, cheering, people calling your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching me. I am very focused. I know many people around the world are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final. It is the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me it was the biggest tournament. When I was 14, I told my friends I wanted to play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice. In 2006, I was happy to be there, but Federer beat me easily. In 2007, I was very sad because I knew I could have played better. I cried a lot after losing. Toni, who is a tough coach, told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it was my last chance. I know a sports career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are very important, and I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I had another chance in 2008. I was sure I learned from my loss. I believed I would win. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends. We did not talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She loved Africa and stayed there for most of her life. Jane was a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, she became famous for her work with chimpanzees. She wrote books for children and adults. One of her books, "In the Shadow of Man," is very popular and has been translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is a famous female scientist. She helped us understand chimpanzees better. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees eat meat or use tools. They also did not know that chimpanzees have emotions like humans. Jane Goodall's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Her study of chimpanzees in Gombe, Nigeria, is a great scientific achievement. Even as a child, Jane was curious. When she was five years old, she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. She hid in a henhouse for five hours to find out. This curiosity helped her become a great biologist.'

'Shirley Ford is a voice actor. She can speak like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. People know her voices from children's TV and cartoons. She also does voices for work programs about health and safety. Shirley says, "I just did a voiceover about back injuries, so I had to learn many medical words."
Shirley talks about voiceover work. "Many actors think they can do funny voices, and they can," she says. "But you need to make the script come alive for people who can't see you." Many famous people want to do voiceovers, but they don't always get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.
After school, Shirley took a drama course. She sang jingles for TV ads. One day, a man at the recording studio asked her to try a rabbit voice for a cartoon. She thought it was funny but tried it and got a big part. Shirley found out she was good at voices and wanted to do more voiceover work. "Things just happened for me," she says. "In my second film, I played the main character and her brother and mother."
Adult women often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. It's hard to hire child actors, so companies prefer adults. Shirley learns new voices by watching children's TV. She likes doing cartoons the most, but she also does educational videos and ads. "Ads are hard because you have to sound happy about things you don't care about," she says. "I smile while talking to make my voice sound happy."
The competition for voiceover work is tough. A good showreel, a recording of what you can do, is important. "It's worth making a strong showreel," Shirley says. "There are agencies that help with this." She says she got to the top of her job by working hard and not giving up. "You need to set goals and keep trying," she says.
For people who want to do voiceovers, Shirley suggests going to special workshops. She loves voices and becomes the characters she plays. "If I do an American voice, I might talk like that for hours or days," she says. "My kids are used to me talking in different voices."'

'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. Cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people choose other jobs, like being a lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make money by drawing doodles, but some people do. Most cartoonists have wanted to do it for a long time. I loved comic strips as a child and drew for school papers. I studied graphic design in college. After college, I showed my drawings to companies. A newspaper wanted cartoons about local issues. I drew some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money. To be a cartoonist, you don’t need a degree or much money. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But it’s not easy. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent. The more skills you have, the better. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer and designer. I take any job because you can learn a lot. It helps to be smart and curious. Cartooning is a business. You have to make and sell your work. Good business skills help. Some cartoonists are not great artists but do well because they are good at business. Some people worry about others stealing their ideas. To protect your work, draw a ‘c’ with a circle, write your name and the date. But it’s more likely no one will steal your work. If someone does and it becomes popular online, it can be a good thing!'

'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house. I decided to throw away an electric guitar. My dad gave it to me for my 16th birthday. It was black and made in Japan. I usually keep old things, so why did I want to throw it away? I took it to the rubbish dump. A young man saw me and asked, "Are you throwing that away?" I said yes. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. Later, I felt sad about it. A few months ago, I got an email. It was from a man named Keith Rushton. He said, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar was sold many times. Keith found my name on it and found me online. He wanted to sell it back to me. I was very happy. My dad put name stickers on everything, even my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar. But I switched to electric guitar. It was the time of punk music. When I got my guitar back, I remembered my birthday in 1978. My parents gave it to me. I played it again. It felt good. Now, I want to play in a band. My son plays the saxophone. Maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people like me. We could call our band ‘The Regainers’!'

'People talk a lot about sleep now. I wrote a book called Insomniac about people who cannot sleep. Sleep is very important for our mind, body, and mood. People who cannot sleep know this well. It is good that sleep is getting attention. But what about dreams? We do not hear much about dreams. We lose dreams when we wake up early. The last part of sleep is called REM, and it is when we dream the most. A good sleeper spends a quarter of sleep time in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they spend six or seven years in REM. Dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM. Sigmund Freud, a famous psychologist, said dreams help us understand our mind. But it is not that simple. Now, dream study looks at the physical side of dreams. Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist, says there is not much agreement on dreams. Dreams help us think in new ways. P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams more than others. Creative people use dreams more. But everyone needs to think creatively, not just artists. Dreams help us find new ideas. Stickgold found that people are more original when they wake up from REM. Creativity is important for everyone. We need to think creatively in our daily lives. This is why we need to dream.'

'Susie Ray left London 20 years ago. She moved to a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you see empty frames and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a copyist artist. She paints copies of famous paintings. She can paint like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies look like the real paintings. Art experts sometimes think her copies are originals. The real paintings cost millions of pounds. Susie's copies cost between a few hundred pounds and £12,000. Many people want her paintings. Her clients include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors pretend her copies are real. Susie signs her name on the back of her paintings. It is against the law to sell a copy as the real thing. Susie does not do this. She was an illustrator before becoming a copyist. She worked at a botanical garden. She learned to draw very accurately. Susie tells young artists to learn to draw well. She likes painting French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie does not paint her own art. She tried once, but she prefers making copies. Susie is a perfectionist.'

**Text for A1 Level:**
Ellen MacArthur loved the sea. She wanted to be the fastest on the water. As a child, she dreamed of sailing. She felt very close to her boats. They were like one team. On land, she missed the ocean. She liked to race and test herself. 
Ellen raced in the Vendée Globe. It is a big race around the world. She came second. Her boat was called Kingfisher. She lived on the boat for 94 days. She planned everything carefully. She had food, a small stove, and medical supplies. The boat was her home.
Ellen went to South Georgia, an island. She saw old whaling stations. This made her think. She wanted to help the planet. She says we must save resources like coal, oil, and gas. We need to use things again and again.
Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation. It helps young people think about a better future. She talks to factories and governments. She wants to save the planet. Ellen says this work is very important. She misses the sea, but this is her new adventure.

**Text for A1 Level:**
Jordan Romero is 13 years old. He wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he will be very famous. Many young people play on computers and games. Jordan wants to show kids they can climb mountains too. Or just go outside. 
Jordan's team is his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is part of their big plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and another mountain in Antarctica, he will be the youngest to climb the Seven Summits. These are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are 30 years old. Jordan has already climbed five of them. 
Some people think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young person might be strong, but maybe not ready in their mind. They also think a young person might not have enough experience. 
The Romeros know people say this. Paul says, 'I know people talk, but we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe in our experience. Jordan is getting strong and grown-up.'
I wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it his father's idea? Paul says, 'This is not about me. Jordan wanted to do it later, but we thought: why not now? We talk to him to make sure he still wants to do it.'
When I ask Jordan why he likes the challenge, he says, 'I just want to reach my goal.'
Today, many people want to be the youngest or fastest to do something. They write about it online. Jordan has to do this too. He needs to blog, take photos, and give interviews. He needs to do something big, like climbing Everest.
Paul says, 'If Jordan wants to stop climbing and play basketball, we will stop and go to the gym.'

'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they do not know him. I am studying music at university, but my classmates do not know much about classical music either. If you do not know the music, you probably do not have any recordings of it. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and classical CDs sell only about 300 copies each. This is surprising to me. Why do people not like classical music anymore? Older people say it is because of TV and video games, but I do not think so. Classical music is not very interesting to most people, especially teenagers. Teenagers buy most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who like classical music, but they are few. I play in an orchestra, but I am not a big fan of classical music. I like many types of music, but I listen to classical music only a little. Why do teenagers not like classical music? Classical music changes mood a lot, and teenagers like things fast. Experts say we cannot pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for classical music but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, and it talks about things teenagers care about. In the past, families played music together at home, and people went to concerts to hear music. Now, we can find any music online, but we do not often listen to classical music. You do not hear classical music in shops. One of my teachers says more people go to classical concerts now, but not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play in many places, but the audience is mostly older people. Teenagers often do not like what their parents like. Some say schools are to blame, but many kids like to play classical music in school orchestras. They practice a lot, but when they relax, they listen to pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mom's car and looked at Almonside School. "I'll make you sorry I'm here," she said to the school. Her mom didn't hear her. Almonside School was strange, with many buildings hidden in the trees. There were signs: Science block, gym, riding center. "Riding center," Bonnie said, interested. "Headmaster's office," her mom said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mom. "Walk next to me," her mom said, tired. But Bonnie didn't. 
Soon, her mom talked to the headmaster in his office. Bonnie waited outside. Then she stood up. "Why should I sit here?" she thought. "I'll leave soon anyway," she thought. She went to the riding center. There was a nice building for horses and a big place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around. No one was there. She liked horses and treated them well. The horses looked well cared for. She looked at each horse. "I know what they're doing here," she told a small pony. 
Then she saw a special horse. "You're the best!" she said. He was brown with some white. His name was Maverick. She wanted to ride him. "Where can I find a bridle and saddle?" she wondered. She found the room with riding equipment. It was open. She put a saddle on Maverick. She forgot about her mom and the headmaster. 
On the horse, she felt like a queen. Her old school called her Queen Bee. She laughed. "You're the best horse," she said to Maverick. "I know about horses." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay, we can be friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The ride was exciting. She felt Maverick trusted her. She was sure he would jump well.

"I met Cody Simpson before. He is a 15-year-old boy from Australia. Cody sings very well. He started playing guitar when he was six. He wrote songs when he was seven. Cody liked swimming and surfing. He went to high school and posted videos online. People liked his videos. They wanted more. Cody was also a good swimmer. He trained with great coaches. But then, music companies called him. Cody had to choose: stay in Australia and swim or move to the US and sing. Cody chose to sing. He moved to the US with his family. It was hard for him to decide. He told his coach and friends he was leaving. They were surprised. Cody is a quiet and modest person. His family helps him. They stay in the background. Cody thinks it is important to have good people around. Sometimes, Cody worries about his brother and sister. They travel a lot and do school on the road. But his family supports him. Cody says success comes from saying 'yes' to big chances, even if it is scary. He travels to many countries and sings for many fans. Cody knows it will not last forever."

'I got out of bed and looked out the window. I saw a crack in the ice on the river. The sun was shining. I looked at the sandbags by the river. They stop the water from flooding the buildings. Last week, I helped put the sandbags there. My back still hurt from lifting them. I worked with many people from the town. My grandfather did not notice. I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I did not know him. He was trying to walk on the ice. I put on my kayaking wetsuit and jacket. I checked my pocket for a silver chain. My grandfather gave it to me. He got it from South America. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow. I went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said. I took a banana. ‘You’re up early. Be careful,’ she said. ‘Thanks, Mom,’ I said. I walked down the hall and almost bumped into Grandpa. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he said. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ He knows I kayak every morning. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. I took a deep breath. He went into the bathroom. Mom smiled at me. ‘Don’t mind him,’ she said. ‘He’s not himself.’ I used to think Grandpa was a hero. He was in National Geographic magazine. His photos and medals are in his room. I don’t go there now. I have my own trophies. I want to be in National Geographic too. But I still care about him. ‘Have a good session, Rex,’ Mom said. ‘I admire your determination!’ I smiled. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed. I ate my banana and went outside to the boathouse.'

Mum held Jess's arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table was a painting by Grandpa. It was not finished. "Do you know about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I have never seen it before," she said. The painting showed a river. It was not a real river, maybe a fantasy one. The picture was strange but beautiful. There were no animals or people. It felt right that way. Mum said, "It has a name." Grandpa never named his pictures. Mum turned the picture over. Jess read the words, "River Boy." There was no boy in the picture. "Strange, isn’t it?" Mum said. "Maybe he will add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You know better," Jess said. "I know, but it is unusual. You can guess what he said." Jess knew. Grandpa always said a picture has its own life. He did not like to explain his paintings. Mum laughed. "I hoped you knew something about it. You are like a muse for him." "Muse?" Jess asked. "Someone who inspires an artist," Mum said. Jess knew the word. Grandpa used it when she watched him paint. But she thought a muse was a goddess, not a person. "He does not need me to inspire him," Jess said. "He has been painting all his life."

'This morning, I did not plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. It was not an accident, but it could have been. Maybe if I tripped with Dad's knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet. I did not want to damage the carpet. I did not wake up and think, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is small, white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept ornaments in it. I keep shells and stones there. I love the cabinet. But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It needs a corner. My bedroom has only two corners. My room is small, under the roof, and shaped like cheese. The big bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I will be in my small room for a long time. I like my room. It is cosy, like a nest. The roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The problem is, there are not enough corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a bit too tall. I thought, if I cannot cut the cabinet, maybe I can cut the carpet. It seemed like a good idea. Dad calls this lateral thinking. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. That is what I was doing!'

'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of very small people. They live in the walls and floors of a house. They take things from big people to live. I was asked to make a TV show of the book. It was hard because people love the book and have strong ideas about it. I used the book's drawings a lot. The author wanted the show to be from the Borrowers' view, not humans'. This made filming hard. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans. So, we filmed from far away. The crew had to film from low down to see like the Borrowers. They wore out many jeans! We never lifted the cameras high, except for special shots. A big challenge was making the shadows look right. We made a special way to do this. After the show, a famous director, George Lucas, called to ask how we did it. We built the Borrowers' home under the floor with big objects to make actors look small. It was funny. The actors carried big things like giant scissors. The coins were bigger than plates and hard to lift. We often stopped filming because the crew laughed. In one scene, the Borrowers go down a drain. Actors went down a tunnel with water hoses. It was scary, so they didn’t have to act scared. Costumes were important. They were made from heavy cloth. The lead actress couldn’t bend or sit. She was sewn into her dress every day. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug. It was hot during filming, and the actors didn’t like the costumes. We filmed the actors in front of a blue screen. They had to act with things that were not there. I drew 2,000 pictures to show how scenes should look. We didn’t have much money, so I worked at night. Once, I filmed a scene with no film in the camera. But in the end, the show was good and showed the magic of the books.'

'Mom stops the car at my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously. I tell her, ‘Everything’s going to be fine.’ She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek. Then she drives away. I am alone at this new school. I wanted to come here to meet real kids. I walk into the school office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule please,’ I say to the secretary. ‘Name?’ she asks. ‘Desert McGraw,’ I say. She looks confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types on her keyboard. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One second, it’s printing,’ she says. She gives me the paper. English Literature is my first class. I like English. I go to Room 214 on the second floor. I hear the teacher taking roll. I sit down quietly. The girl next to me smiles. ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look at my shoes. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher calls my name, ‘Desert McGraw?’ ‘Here,’ I say. The teacher smiles and says her name is Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. Then she lets us talk. ‘Why’d you move here?’ the girl asks. I think about what to say. ‘My dad had to relocate,’ I tell her. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say. ‘Cool. I’m Becca,’ she says. She doesn’t seem to care much. Great.'

'American teenage girls have many things to do. They need to be good at school, have a job, and help others. This is normal for teenagers today. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and do nothing else. They have a lot of homework, tests, and activities. They also have jobs and chores at home. Teenager Kristen Loose says people forget how much work teenagers have. Some people think teenagers are lazy and rude. But not all teenagers are like this. Kristen says teenagers use their phones to help them. Phones help them do homework and stay in touch. Teenagers start their day early and finish late. They do not get enough sleep. Only 20% of teenagers sleep nine hours a night. Many fall asleep in school. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen has only 18 hours of free time a week. She uses this time to help others. She likes to volunteer and help her community. In the future, teenagers will still work hard and change the world.'

'The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. This group has sent over fifty balloons high into the sky, about 35 km above the Earth. It is a science project and an adventure. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are going to release a balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal enters the Earth's atmosphere and makes a light. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are outside the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank fills the balloon, which grows big like a small car. An older boy drove a long way to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time to let the balloon go. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they say, and the balloon goes up. Some of them run and watch it with flashlights. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and sleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ says one girl. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, it gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box come back to Earth safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS. Finding it is not easy, but they like the challenge. The lunch box usually lands far from people. ‘Finding the lunch box is a big part of the fun,’ says the group’s leader. They have lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. The team had to drive around the mountains to get it. They had to decide if driving or walking was better. It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was on a rock in a waterfall. The camera did not record any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but they talked about why it happened. It was another adventure to share with others.'

"When you travel by car with your family, you often ask, 'Are we there yet?' But when you arrive, it is not 'there' anymore. It is 'here.' So, you should ask, 'Are we here yet?' Parents want to be 'there' more than kids because kids can relax in the back seat. Kids can watch DVDs, listen to music, and do puzzles. Parents give juice boxes and cookies and make sure everything is okay. But sometimes, kids fight. My brother Tim puts his foot on my side. I put my foot on his side. We fight, and parents have to stop us. Then, Tim blows air on me, and we fight again. Dad has a plan for us. When we ask, 'Are we there yet?' he says, 'Yes, get out of the car.' But we are still on the highway. So, we know we are not there yet. You know you are 'there' when parents get out of the car and walk away. If they are still in the car, you are not there yet."

'John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK. People can drink coffee, eat cake, and play board games there. John and Zuzi want people to have fun and come back. Zuzi says they started the café because people use phones and gadgets too much. They want people to talk and be together. The games in the café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games have gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, made by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade. Everyone stays involved until the end. Some games are ‘co-operative’, where players win or lose together. Pandemic is a co-operative game made by Matt Leacock from North America. Players work together to solve problems. Leacock loved games as a child but was often disappointed. He and his uncle tried to make better games. Pandemic was very successful. It has a lot of storytelling, like video games. Video games helped board games become popular. Many people play games on their phones now. Video games and board games learn from each other. People used to play video games together in the same room. Now, many play online, away from each other. Some people want to play games with others in person again. John and Zuzi's café is busy because people like to play games together in real life.'

Jamie Scott is a famous music writer and producer from the UK. He believes that working hard is important in music. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him guitar. He listened to local radio at home, which influenced him. He first heard modern music at age 12. Jamie played tennis very well, but he loved music more. He spent time in the school music room playing piano. At 17, he left school to become a performer. He was in a music duo with a friend, but his friend did not want a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to write songs. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed or get a job. At 19, he got a music deal because of one song. He had to leave his friend because record labels wanted him solo. Jamie found success writing songs for others. He helps new artists and wants to write big hit songs. Jamie is honest about wanting to write number one songs. He believes he has the talent to do it. In the studio, he aims to write the best music for the next year. He wants to create classic modern pop songs.

'Tony Connor is a new kind of famous person. He is very popular online, but many people do not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist'. He jumps from places like roofs and walls on his bike. People film his jumps and put them online. I met Tony in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. Many local boys know him, and some older people call him a 'legend'. After watching him, I agree he is very brave and creative. Tony is famous online, but he does not like being a celebrity. He says, 'I find it hard to talk to fans. I like doing things more than talking about them.' Tony's fame comes from social media and cameras. He says, 'This technology helps me make a living.' But he also thinks people spend too much time with cameras and screens. Tony makes money from his videos, which used to be just a hobby. I learned that to be a top athlete, you need energy and the ability to keep going after failure. Tony shows this by trying again after falling. Some people think Tony takes too many risks. He says they do not understand his sport. Tony is careful and plans a lot. He says, 'I feel fear but find a way past it. I am not addicted to risk. I prepare a lot before trying a new jump. I must be brave when I jump.'

'Helen Skelton is a TV presenter. She does dangerous things to help charity. She ran a marathon in the desert and went down the Amazon river in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire. The wire was 66 meters above the ground. It was between two towers of an empty power station. She had no safety net. She wore a belt attached to another wire above her. She carried a long stick to help her balance. The stick was eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert. She found high-wire walking very hard. She trained every day. She ran up a hill and did exercises. She learned how to fall on the wire safely. Falling hurt, but she stayed positive. On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen took deep breaths and walked slowly. It took 15 minutes to walk 150 meters. She said it was very scary. But she is planning her next charity project. She wants to go to the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

'In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing. A penny farthing is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Jeff had already written a book about traveling in Canada in an old car. He loved motor sports and worked on racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even went to Amsterdam on it for a holiday. ‘That trip made me want to see the world by bike,’ he says. Jeff didn’t want a normal bike. He wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bike I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two tries in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally started in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was seeing Mount Everest in Tibet. ‘I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I couldn’t do, but I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I went, the more amazed people were by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and stayed in bed for ten days without medicine. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. But Jeff says, ‘if I could afford it, I would travel again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’'

'I work at a university in the US. My team and I study water birds. We are learning about a bird called the American black duck. We use a special tool called a 'night-vision scope'. It helps us see ducks in the dark. We are worried because there are fewer black ducks now. We do not know if they have enough food on the east coast. We know what they do in the day, but not at night. The new scope gives us clear pictures at night. This helps us learn more and take care of their home. Our work is hard. Four people work six hours each day. We study ducks in different places. I take a boat to some places and write notes about the ducks. The weather is not always good. Some nights are nice, but many are wet. It is very quiet, so I drink coffee to stay awake. We only missed one day because of deep snow. I like the challenge. In summer, we will work in a lab to look at our results. It will be hard to stay inside, but it is important. I would not change my job for anything!'

'When I tell people about my job, they are surprised. But it is true! I eat chocolate for my job. I taste chocolate to make sure it is good for customers. Every week, I get small pieces of chocolate from our factory. I check them for taste, feel, and smell. I also taste nuts and fruit we use in the chocolate. I choose the best ones. Next to my office, I have a kitchen. I test and taste chocolate there. I give my work friends some chocolate too! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients. It is nice to have my own space. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I am in the food lab. Other times, I travel to buy nuts and fruit. I have a young family, so travel can be hard. But I like the change and not having a routine. I love my job, especially the chocolate! People ask if I get tired of chocolate. I have worked with chocolate for a long time, and I still like to eat it. I even eat more chocolate at home in the evening!'

'Have you ever thought about working in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience. It is a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many things. You can learn to juggle, throw and catch balls, and even fire. You can also learn trapeze, which is flying in the air. Students take a year-long course. They slowly learn to take more risks. Parents can watch some classes. Sophia says, "In the circus, you must do new things. You need to keep shows exciting. To be good in the circus, you must practice a lot. You also make friends and learn from them. Being fit is important. Circus artists train every day to stay strong. The best performers want to be better and have new ideas." People think you might get hurt or work only a little each year. But you need to plan for the future because you can only work in the circus when you are young. The course also teaches business planning. Many students start businesses around the world. They like to share their stories. Sophia says it is not a job to make a lot of money. "The work does not have a regular salary. It is competitive but very fun!"'

'You may not know her name or her face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a backing singer. She sings behind the main singer. Some people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers. That is not true. They have to be very good. People like Mariam are important in music! Mariam says, ‘I love my job because I never know what I will sing in the studio. It can be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes it is a funny song for a radio or an ad. Once, I had to sing like a fish underwater! But I never say no, I just do my job!’ ‘I need to be very good at music and learn fast. There is often no music to read. I remember my first time recording music for a film. It was hard because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared: if I made a mistake, we had to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording takes a long time.’ ‘One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. New songwriters do not always know what is best for a female voice. When they hear me sing their song, they can see how to make it better.’'

'Julie Deane started with little fashion knowledge. She made a business with 'satchels' - a traditional school bag. These bags are now in famous shops and used by celebrities. Before choosing satchels, Julie thought about other businesses like cake decorating. Some people said satchels would not sell, but Julie believed in them. She worked with her mother, who is good at business. The bag design came from children's story books. Julie did not know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her. At first, she sold one satchel a week. She sent satchels to fashion writers, and they wrote about them. Now, many people want her bags. Julie likes to see which celebrity has a satchel. She uses the internet for new ideas. One time, another company copied her design. Now, she trusts her team to make good bags. People say her office is a happy place. There is a new factory, but the team makes it special.'

'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky chose to do many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling. He bought a special bike and started racing. Vicky thought it looked fun and tried it too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon she was cycling every day and doing well. The track was near her school, so she could train after school every day. Vicky had a successful career in cycling and won many races. Then, at 28, she stopped racing. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning, but I got tired. When the fun stops, there’s no point.’ She started a new job. Vicky works for a charity called CycleZone. ‘We help young people who don’t like sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves. CycleZone is great because it brings young people together.’ The charity uses famous people to talk about their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people think celebrities only help to be more famous. But if they can help, I think they should.’'

'Ana Ronson is a singer and songwriter. She is from Ireland. Her parents did not play music, but her grandfather did. He played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. Ana first sang in front of people at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher helped her. The teacher told her to join the school theatre club. This helped Ana feel better about singing. Later, Ana's brother asked her to write a song for his band. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in three days. Ana liked writing songs, so she took a songwriting class. She was the youngest student, but she knew a lot about music. Ana wrote a song called Something to Say because she was upset with her teacher. She put the song online, and many people liked it. Joss Alton, who owns a music company, asked Ana to join his company. At first, Ana was not sure, but Joss said she could sing what she wanted. Ana then sang at a concert in Dublin. It was a great night. Ana likes to write songs about difficult times. One song, Decision, is about her brother stopping singing and feeling sad. Ana wants people to like her songs, but she writes about things that are important to her.'

'Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat with a group along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not. I wanted to visit the area because I saw it on TV when I was a child. Our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I asked Harry if I could go too, and he said yes! Before we left, there were storms in the area. But the weather was good when we were there. I was busy at work, so I did not have much time to plan. But Harry said he took care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After we arrived in Canada, we joined the group. We packed our things into small boats and left. The guide said not many people live along that coast. We only saw dolphins and birds on the first morning. There were islands far away, but it was foggy, so we could not see them well. I watched the patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped to look at rock pools on the beaches. They had many colorful fish. I did not know many of them. We did not worry about time.
